 AZERBAIJAN REPUBLIC GREATER BAKU WATER SUPPLY REHABILITATION PROJECT Credit and Project Summary Borrower: Azerbaijan Republic Beneficiary: Apsheron Regional Water Company (ARWC) Amount: SDR 38.8 Million (US$61 Million Equivalent) Terms: IDA Standard with 35-years' maturity, including 10 years of grace. Onlending Terms: Ministry of Finance will onlend the IDA and EBRD funds to the ARWC over 25 years, including 5 years of grace, at 7 percent interest. Objectives: The primary objectives of the Project are to: (a) make emergency short term improvements in the water supply system to restore the water supply to Baku, in particular to the poorer elements of the population; (b) improve the water supply system as a whole; and (c) provide the basis for longer term planning and recovery. Project Description: The Project will comprise five major components: Water Demand Management - conserving water at the household level through a program of consumer awareness initiatives, through repairs to in-home plumbing, valves, taps and other fittings, and by rationalizing water use through meter installations and the implementation of a progressive water tariff; Operations and Maintenance Improvements - increasing the amount of water available from the distribution system through a program of leak detection and repair, workshop and equipment acquisition, and at least a one year inventory of selected replacement valves and pipes; Supply Improvements - improving the quantity and quality of water from the treatment works and enhancing the reliability of the distribution network through a program of selective rehabilitation of the major water treatment plants and pumping stations; Institutional Capacity Building - reorganizing the water utility into a joint stock company (ARWC); consolidating its offices in a new headquarters building; strengthening its institutional capacity through a twinning arrangement with an experienced water utility; purchase and installation of computers and requisite software programs; and the development and implementation of training programs aimed at improving both operational and administrative effectiveness; and Studies - preparation and implementation of a national policy framework for the water sector, preparation of a regional water supply and sewerage master
 - jj - plan, and the development of a second phase Project. Project Benefits: The Project is the least-cost solution in terms of yielding maximum benefits and significantly reducing the public health risks associated with the existing quantity and quality of water. The benefits resulting from the project would include: (i) an improvement in public health standards by reducing the incidence of waterborne and water related diseases; and (ii) a reduction in the need to invest in "coping" mechanisms by the families who do not get adequate water. In financial terms, the poor would benefit most from an improved supply system. However, in terms of improved water quality, both low and high-income families would benefit in equal proportions. Further, improvements to the quality and quantity of water extend beyond Baku to the half million or more people living within the metropolitan region. The Project will also assist the productive sectors by increasing the availability of a critically needed commodity, notably a reliable and sustainable supply of potable water. Environmental Impact: An environmental review has been prepared consistent with the provisions of the World Bank's Operational Directive 4.01, "Environmental Assessment" and the applicable environmental procedures of the Government of Azerbaijan. The Project has been placed in environmental screening category "B", since most of the potential impacts are expected to be beneficial. Project Risks: There are risks inherent to a first-time investment operation for a new borrower. These risks include: (a) delays in Project implementation due to the limited experience of ARWC in this type of activity; (b) possible understatement of construction costs due to the limited experience of ARWC with actual costs for implementation and previous lack of construction experience to meet international standards in this sector; (c) reluctance of the Government to face up to the challenges of implementing the requisite sector and institutional reforms; (d) underestimating the extraordinary effort and long-term commitment required to achieve financial viability in the water supply sector; and (e) unrealistic and hence demoralizing expectations that the Baku water supply crisis could be resolved quickly. These risks will be reduced through the early establishment of a twinning arrangement with another water utility, by significant supervision by staff from Bank headquarters, by the use of appropriate physical and price contingencies, by the on-going dialogue with the Government and ARWC, by building the capacity of ARWC to carry out its responsibilities effectively through extensive technical assistance support, and by an extensive public information/education program to be financed under the Project.  AZERBAIJAN REPUBLIC GREATER BAKU WATER SUPPLY REHABILITATION PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. COUNTRY AND SECTOR BACKGROUND A. Country Context 1.1 Country Profile. Azerbaijan lies on the southeastern flanks of the Caucasus mountains, bounded on the north by Georgia and the Russian Federation, on the east by the Caspian Sea, on the south by the Islamic Republic of Iran, and on the west by Armenia (see IBRD Map No. 26892). It is one of the smallest countries of the Former Soviet Union (FSU), covering an area of about 86,000 kIn2, similar to Austria. Azerbaijan is endowed with fertile agricultural land and natural resources, including substantial underdeveloped petroleum reserves, and contains one of the oldest oil-producing regions of the world. Oil production has been declining, however, because existing fields have reached a state of advanced depletion and agreements to develop new fields are only now being concluded. The country also has a diversified industrial structure, a relatively well-educated labor force, and a buoyant and rapidly expanding private sector. 1.2 The population of Azerbaijan is estimated at about 7.4 million people in 1993, compared to 6 million in 1979 and 5.1 million in 1970. These statistics indicate a declining growth rate, from 1.7 percent per annum during the period 1970-79, to about 1.2 percent during the period 1989-93. By 1993, over half of the population lived in urban areas. 1.3 Notwithstanding its political independence in 1991, Azerbaijan has continued to remain closely tied to the FSU. The country remained in the ruble zone throughout 1992, and the deeply entrenched economic interdependence continues. In addition to transitional difficulties, the unsettled situation in Nagorno-Karabakh and the continuous conflict with Armenia has contributed to a drastic decline in output. The large number of refugees (about one million) and the occupation of territories by Armenian forces have been a major contributor to political instability in the country. As a result, Azerbaijan has undergone frequent governmental changes. These unfavorable developments have also been influential in diverting the Government's attention away from addressing the economic and reform challenges facing the nation. 1.4 During 1992, after three years of relatively small declines, Azerbaijan's economy underwent a particularly sharp contraction with a rapid acceleration of inflation. These trends continued into 1993 and early 1994. Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in 1993 was only about 60 percent of its 1988 level. The worsening economic situation in 1993 was also marked by a serious deterioration in both fiscal and external balances. Nonetheless, the Government initiated reform measures to liberalize the economy and ensure the transition to a market economy. In this connection, the Government took an early decision to introduce a national currency, the manat, liberalized most prices, initiated financial sector reforms, and began developing the necessary legal and institutional framework to support these changes. On the other hand, enterprise restructuring and land reform were limited. However, the recent cease-fire and the improved prospects for peace in Nagorno-Karabakh have strengthened the Government's determination to accelerate comprehensive reforms. The Government has concluded the purchase under the IMF's Systemic Transformation Facility for a comprehensive program of stabilization and structural reform, and has requested the Bank to support its reform efforts with a Rehabilitation Credit.
 B. Regional Context 1.5 Greater Baku. Because the economy of Azerbaijan relies heavily on a diversified range of activities performed by the Central Government, Baku dominates the metropolitan region. Its position as the seat of Government and the principal educational, cultural and industrial center of the country, further increases its attractiveness to the most talented professionals, who are reluctant to locate outside of the city because of less promising career prospects. Thus, the urban structure of Azerbaijan exhibits a striking degree of primacy, with more than two-thirds of the urban population or 2.5 million people concentrated in Greater Baku'. As shown in Table 1.1, the 1993 population of Baku was estimated at about 1.7 million inhabitants, but this figure may have increased to more than 2 million as a result of the influx of refugees from the conflict in and around Nagorno-Karabakh. However, it is envisaged that future population growth will be moderate and many of the refugees are expected to return to their homes once the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict is resolved. With the population of Greater Baku projected to reach only about 2.8 million people by the year 2015, demographic pressures arising from rapid population growth are not expected to be significant in the demand for urban services. Early records mention the existence of Baku in the fifth century, although present-day Baku did not really begin to develop until the middle of the nineteenth century when the first oil well was drilled in Bibi-Eibat (1847) on the western promontory of Baku Bay. Additional oil developments followed in the second half of the nineteenth century, and by the beginning of the twentieth century, the area accounted for about 50 percent of the world's crude oil production. This new wealth sparked the development of Baku's western waterfront with the construction of mansions, schools, libraries, hospitals, parks and gardens, hotels, concert halls, museums, and an opera house. The city's first public water supply system was constructed in 1917. Present-day Baku has all of the basic attributes of a modern urban center, including an extensive transport network, an underground metro system, an international airport, and the largest port on the Caspian Sea (nine general cargo berths, a ferry terminal, and specialized facilities for dry and liquid bulk cargoes). Many of these facilities, however, suffer from significant deferred maintenance. A high proportion of the population in Greater Baku is recorded as economically active--1992 estimates indicate a participation rate of 55 percent (which is common in central and Eastern Europe, but is high in comparison to Western Europe). The unemployment rate was estimated at 10 percent in 1992, although this figure may have risen sharply in the light of the difficult economic conditions and the decline in industrial capacity utilization following the collapse of the guaranteed market under the FSU. In Greater Baku, industry accounts for about 25 to 30 percent of employment, while government, conmmercial and service sectors represents a further 50 to 55 percent of employment. There are more than 400 industrial plants in the metropolitan region, mainly comprising oil refining, chemicals, engineering, and machinery. This industrial base is complemented by a broad range of medium-scale industries, notably food processing, tobacco and beverages, textiles, consumer goods, building materials, metal and metal products, electrical equipment, plastics, and rubber products. 1.8 Health Profile. General health indicators show that in 1990 life expectancy at birth was 71 years of age, with infant mortality at 23 per 1,000 live births. These levels compare favorably with other Central Asian Republics, but there is cause for concern that the general social and health conditions may decline in light of the current economic crisis and the rapid deterioration of basic infrastructure and environmental facilities. Morbidity figures indicate a high incidence of hospitalized cases of waterborne and water-related diseases. Moreover, recent data suggest that the more life-threatening diseases such as typhoid/para-typhoid, viral hepatitis, and cholera are spreading in the region. 1.9 Climatic and Spatial Characteristics. The capital city of Baku is located on the edge of Baku Bay on the southern side of the long narrow Apsheron Peninsula, which extends about 60 km into the Caspian Sea. The prevailing climate on the peninsula is dry and subtropical in the summer with average daily temperatures of about +260 C in July and August, and dry and cold in the winter with average daily temperatures of about +30 C in January. Annual precipitation is 110 to 250 nun per year, and falls mainly in early spring and late autumn. Because of these climatic conditions, Baku traditionally has had to rely on distant water sources to satisfy domestic, industrial, and agricultural demand (see IBRD Map No. 26892). The spatial distribution of the city is divided into four main zones: (a) the Central Business District (CBD), with a population density of about 2,679 people per km2, faces the waterfront at the western end of Baku Bay and comprises the old city, most central government organizations, commercial offices, cultural amenities and almost all of the hotels. A large industrial area is also located at the western point of the bay along with oil wells; (b) the Central Eastern Area, with a population density of about 6,719 people per krn2, also fronts the bay and comprises large industrial enterprises, heavy industries, informal settlements established near the factories, and numerous high-rise apartment buildings along the periphery; (c) the Western Area, with population densities ranging between 13,375 and 19,900 people per km2, is dominated by residential high-rise apartment buildings, although future expansion is constrained by the surrounding hills; and (d) the Eastern Area, with population densities ranging between 770 people and 7,950 people per kmi2, comprises both medium and heavy industries, residential development and small- scale garden agriculture.
 -4 - C. Sectoral Context 1.10 Institutional Setting. In the past, control over fiscal management and national and regional planning was highly centralized in Moscow. Since independence, these functions have been assumed by the national government, but continue to be administered through a conunand-style hierarchy similar to that which existed before. Jurisdictionally, the water supply and sewerage sector is the responsibility of the following five ministries: (a) Ministry of Irrigation (MOI) - is responsible for the overall national water balance including the allocation of surface water resources between potable water and agricultural use, and is also responsible for the operation, maintenance and ownership of all dams, canals and lakes; (b) Ministry of Geology (MOG) - responsible for all groundwater resources and is the originating agency for issuing groundwater extraction licenses as well as serving as an advisor to the various Governmental agencies on matters associated with water resource development; (c) Ministry of Health (MOH) - responsible for setting the quality standards for drinking water, although in practice there is little or no effective enforcement of those standards, despite the fact that many water samples in the Baku area do not meet the required standards; (d) State Ecology Committee (SEC) - responsible for regulating environmental standards-- while this agency is developing an appropriate legislative framework, effective enforcement is constrained by lack of resources due to the current economic situation; and (e) Ministry of Housing and Communal Property (MOHCP) - owns and operates regional and municipal water supply and sewerage agencies, which are responsible for the bulk transmission, treatment and distribution of potable water and the collection and disposal of sewage. The exception is rural areas, which fall under the jurisdiction of the MOI, and which are usually supplied by pipelines with the dual function of providing both agricultural and domestic water. 1.11 Sewerage services are provided by the MOHCP in conjunction with the municipalities. To optimize potential benefits of lower overheads and common maintenance facilities, there is a strong view within the sector that water and sewerage services should be administered by a single agency. This view has considerable merit and will be addressed in the context of a water and sewerage master plan to be financed under the Project. 1.12 Water Service Levels. In large urban areas, more than 95 percent of all households and industrial users are directly connected to the public water supply system. However, in the allocation of piped water between domestic and industrial consumers, industry has historically received priority according to planned quotas determined by the type of product and capacity of each individual factory. Even in times of acute water shortages, priority has gone to serving the needs of industry first. Domestic water rationing, therefore, has always been the norm. Recently the problem has been amplified, mostly because of a marked physical deterioration in the systems. In the larger urban areas, many households
 - 5 - are restricted to six hours or less of piped water per day. 1.13 To gain a better idea about the potential impact of water service levels on Baku residents, IDA initiated and designed a household survey/social assessment in July 1994, which was carried out by the Azerbaijan Institute of Social Management and Political Sciences in conjunction with the State University of Baku. The major findings of the social assessment on service levels are summarized in para 2.13 and described more fully in Annex A. 1.14 The objectives of the social assessment were to identify key stakeholders and to propose an appropriate framework for their participation in project design and implementation, to evaluate the social impact of the proposed interventions on households and to investigate whether certain social groups may be adversely affected, to design social mitigation measures for those who would experience negative impacts if necessary, and to ensure that project objectives and incentives for change are appropriate and acceptable to all beneficiaries. The social assessment consisted of a rapid household survey, undertaken with the assistance of local academicians and researchers, community-based discussions conducted through informal household visits and interviews, informal interviews with private sector providers of water, and case studies of a small subset of households from the rapid appraisal sample. 1.15 Sewerage Service Levels. Sewerage service levels are even lower than those for water. In the larger urban areas, one-third of the population is not connected to a municipal sewerage system. In the case of adjacent towns and villages outside of Greater Baku but still within the Apsheron Peninsula, none of the urban centers have proper sewerage systems and virtually none of these areas have treatment facilities. In fact, sewage is usually discharged into the nearest lake or ground soakway. Existing sewerage systems are in poor condition, leading to groundwater contamination and imminent risk of polluting the water supply system through pipes built too closely together. The rising water level of many of the natural lakes on the Peninsula is attributed to wastewater discharge. In the smaller urban and rural areas the situation is even more precarious. 1.16 Constraints to Water Sector Development. Three major constraints have been identified that significantly impede the development of the sector, notably: (i) the lack of finance for maintenance, rehabilitation, and, in the longer term, new investment; (ii) the lack of a proper policy and analytical framework; and (iii) a non-comrnercial approach to pricing: (a) Lack of Finance. The planning and budgetary process followed by the Government generally, and by the Baku Water Agency (BWA) in particular, does not appear to be sufficiently analytical to help policymakers make the proper determinations that will facilitate overall sectoral efficiency. The sector's budgetary process and the related mechanisms of fiscal management have been described as a chronic shortage of funds coupled with a continuous search for an appropriate balance between competing needs. Thus, the recent economic uncertainties, which have been exacerbated by the Nagomo- Karabakh conflict, and the demand for scarce resources from other sectors, will continue to impose difficulties for the water and sewerage sector in obtaining the resources it needs; (b) Lack of Policy and Analytical Framework. While the jurisdictional fragmentation of the sector is well known and in many respects a holdover from the previous era, it will, nevertheless, require immediate attention if progress is to be made in streamlining the sector. Further, under present arrangements, individual projects are formulated by the
 - 6 - sectoral agency, and the task of producing detailed designs is assigned to state-owned engineering institutes. In the analysis of projects, technical feasibility and compatibility with narrow sectoral objectives appear to be the main emphasis, rather than the economic analysis that would help policymakers make well-informed decisions. While a master plan to be prepared under the Project is expected to provide some of the answers, it is important to emphasize that for a metropolitan region the size and complexity of Greater Baku, the master plan at best can only be a rough, although strategic guide to investment choices; and (c) Pricing. Pricing is a serious issue. Tariffs and charges bear little relation to production and operating costs and sewerage services are provided free. The current low tariff levels represent a major constraint in generating the resources needed to finance a program of rehabilitation and maintenance. Arguably, some of the water "shortages" may well be manifestations of underpricing, despite a consumer willingness to pay at a level that covers the cost of provision. Bank/IDA experience has shown, for example, that the price charged for water and sewerage services signals to the consumer its value--excessively low prices often encourage the consumer to use more than is economically justified. Excessive use of water in Baku is illustrated by the large number of constantly leaking faucets and faulty sanitary fittings in many of the public buildings and private households. 1.17 Environmental Context. The Apsheron Peninsula is the site of one of the three most industrialized regions in the FSU. Its ecosystem is replete with the residue and legacy of nearly a century of environmental neglect. Importantly, this area is one of the oldest oil-producing regions in the world. As a consequence of oil exploitation, as well as intense industrialization under the Soviets, the surface and underground hydrosphere has caused 7,000 ha. of land to be polluted, with a thickness varying from 2.5 to 20 meters. This in turn has led to both flowage and underflooding, created bogs, increased abrasion processes, polluted the Bay of Baku (with environmental imnpact on those who live near the Bay or walk along its perimeter), and engendered serious pollution of the Caspian Sea--the level of which is rising. A further problem pertains to the health care institutions themselves, which discharge biological contaminants directly into the wastewater system. In addition, none of the 92 hospitals and 11 medical institutes in the Baku area is equipped with adequate facilities for treating wastes before discharging them into the municipal network (see IBRD Map No. 26889). 1.18 In the water sector, industrial contamination, generally inadequate water treatment, and unreliable water supply and distribution pose serious social, health, and even industrial problems. Most of the groundwater resources are contaminated by industrial and municipal wastes dumped or discharged haphazardly (see IBRD Map No. 26891). The main source of pollution in the water distribution network is the inflow of dirty groundwater that accumulates as a result of burst water and sewerage pipes which the water company lacks the means to repair (to be addressed under the Project.) 1.19 Finally, there is a notable absence of realistic environmental standards and enforcement mechanisms--although the Soviets developed rigorous guidelines, evidence suggests they were seldom applied. Over time several industries developed their own environmental bureaus which theoretically monitored environmnental impact; however, clearly self-policing has never worked. The result is a widespread lack of coordination of environmental policies and standards. 1.20 There are four agencies involved in environmental monitoring and 200 monitoring sites, including monitoring of marine ecosystems, freshwater, groundwater, and atmospheric pollution. In the
 - 7 - current austere economic climate, lack of resources has seriously jeopardized all such activities, including research. Recently, the State Ecological Committee drafted a package of environmental legislation that incorporates international experience and concerns in the areas where monitoring takes place. This legislation was submitted for parliamentary action in the spring of 1994 and is still pending. Additionally, the National Sanitary Board, in cooperation with the Ecological Commission, has prepared a manual that would establish national enviromnental standards which also awaits parliamentary approval. D. Government Strategy and Bank/IDA Role 1.21 As part of the country's medium-term development program, Government strategy now places high priority on developing the country's natural resources, especially in the petroleum and agricultural sectors; channelling increased revenues toward expenditures and investments that will best contribute to a sustainable and broad-based development; strengthening its transition to a market economy with modern institutions and a flourishing private sector; and providing adequate infrastructure. The Government has held discussions with the IMF on implementing an economic stabilization program, and is seeking assistance from the IMF's Systemic Transformation Facility (STF). It has also requested that the Bank support its efforts with a Rehabilitation Credit, which will be considered in the framework of the Government reaching an understanding with the IMF on the STF program, and with the Bank on a credible program of structural reforms. 1.22 The Bank/IDA assistance strategy aims to support Azerbaijan in its transition to a market economy through policy advice, economic and sector work, and lending for investments and technical assistance (TA). A limited Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) has been developed. The Bank's main focus includes support for economic transformation through assistance for institutional strengthening and related financial support to the economy. At the sectoral level, Bank/IDA expects to focus on projects in the energy, agricultural and social infrastructure sectors. An essential element of the Bank/IDA initial assistance strategy is helping prepare the social safety net for the massive restructuring of the productive sector that lies ahead. Bank/IDA is planning to develop two or three projects per year over fiscal years 1995-97. The amount of annual lending will depend on the pace of reform and resolution of critical external factors, including the regional conflict with Armenia. Azerbaijan became eligible for IDA assistance in December 1994, and the first two projects in the country will be on IDA terms. 1.23 The Greater Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project, which will be the Bank's first infrastructure operation in Azerbaijan, is a critical component in strengthening the Social Safety net. The Project has a strong poverty focus, as it will assist the poorer sections of to gain improved access to an essential service. In addition to serving the residential population, the Project also benefits the productive sectors by increasing the availability of a reliable and sustainable supply of potable water. The Project has been designed with clear and simple objectives to facilitate implementation and have a high chance of achieving its development impact quickly. Specifically, the Project would support the transition process through key policy reforms and adjustment measures in the water sector. These include strengthening cost recovery principles, pursuit of sound financing mechanisms (including financial resource mobilization), and fostering the development of a strong institutional framework to contribute effectively to the country's overall development process. This strategy aims also at institutionalizing a rational decision-making process for new investments in the water and sewerage sector. In the absence of IDA involvement, it is unlikely that the Government would be able to mobilize the financial resources required to implement a water supply project for this economically and environmentally important area of the country.
 -8- E. Bank/IDA Experience in the Sector 1.24 Bank/IDA project experience in Azerbaijan is limited to implementation of Project Preparation Facilities (PPF). This indicates that institutional capacity for implementation is limited, and that responsibilities are often not well delineated between Government and enterprises. Close attention will needed to be paid to procurement, due in part to the lack of familiarity with Bank procedures. Further, the practical aspects of implementation, such as international communications and language difficulties, can create delays. 1.25 The Project design, therefore, has relied on the extensive experience of Bank/IDA in the sector. As of December 31, 1993, Bank lending to the water supply and sewerage sector totalled US$11 billion, funding 277 projects. While most of these projects were successful in achieving their physical objectives and in achieving least cost solutions, there has been limited success in achieving strong and financially viable institutions and poverty relief. In the few cases where physical objectives were not met, the principal cause was cost overruns that resulted in some project components being dropped--mainly those dealing with sanitation and pollution control initiatives. It is noteworthy that cost overruns were seldom caused by poor cost estimating, but rather the consequence of inflation and delays in construction. 1.26 Bank experience also has shown that achieving institutioral and financial viability through project design has proved elusive. In general, measurable success has been achieved only in projects that enjoyed the full commitment of the borrower and substantial resources for training and technical assistance. A recent World Bank study, which examined more than 120 urban water projects between 1967 and 1989, has concluded that despite efforts at capacity building for the public institutions concerned, only four countries--Botswana, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, and Tunisia--have achieved acceptable levels of performance for public water and sewerage utilities. The same report found that the financial performance of water and sewerage agencies was equally poor. Some of the reasons for the less than optimal results, which were also confirmed in the 1994 World Development Report (WDR), include: (i) lack of clear sector policies; (ii) lack of management and financial autonomy; (iii) staff inexperience in project implementation; and (iv) lack of participation by users and other stakeholders in the decision- making process. Few Bank/IDA projects were able to demonstrate measurable success in meeting the needs of the poor. This does not necessarily mean that the projects were unsuccessful, since a major constraint in measuring poverty reduction was the lack of detailed data on the number of poor households and their location, and when success was achieved, the lack of an empirical basis for measuring it. 1.27 In any event, the lessons are clear. From a demand perspective, the message is that the various stakeholders must be trusted to choose from a menu of service levels that they want and are willing to pay for. From a supply perspective, the lesson is that rigorous attention must be paid to water conservation and system optimization, so that households can be provided with a particular level of service at the lowest possible cost. These lessons, to the extent feasible, have been incorporated into the design of the Project in four specific ways: (a) the IDA initiated social assessment was a first step towards generating informed public participation in the design of the Project. The study also demonstrated a clear willingness on the part of the consumer to pay for improved water supply. As a consequence of the assessment, a larger Government constituency is evolving in support of policy and pricing reforms. The question now, therefore, is not what should be done, but rather the conditions

II. PROJECT SETTING AND REFORM STRATEGY A. Project Setting 2.1 Sources of Water. The Greater Baku system obtains water from three separate sources (see IBRD Map No. 26892): (i) Shollar and Hachmas Groundwater Aquifers; (ii) Jeiranbatan Reservoir; and (iii) the Kura River. These sources represent exploitation of both surface and underground resources. The Shollar and Hachmas extraction facilities, generally known as Baku I and Baku 2, respectively, were constructed in 1917 and were the first sources to be developed to serve Baku. Located about 185 kms to the northwest of the city, these sources exploit an aquifer flowing under artesian conditions. 2.2 The Jeiranbatan Reservoir is fed with water by canal from the Samnur River located about 200 km north of Baku on the Russian border. The reservoir has a storage capacity of about 186 million m3 (150 million in3 net) and is recharged at the rate of about 25 m3/s, of which 15 m3/s is earmarked for irrigation purposes. The most significant beneficial feature of the reservoir is that it acts as a long- retention presettlement pond, thus greatly enhancing the final quality of the treated water. However, during the winter months the supply of water is affected by significant seasonal variations due to freezing of the Samur River and the transmission canal. The Kura River originates in Georgia and flows through Azerbaijan where it is joined by the Araks River (which originates from tributaries in Iran and Armenia) en route to the Caspian Sea. Both rivers are reputed to be heavily polluted2 and turbidity levels are high, especially during the spring run-off. 2.3 The Kura, Araks and Samur Rivers are international waterways within the meaning of the World Bank's Operational Directive (OD) 7.50. However, the Project is exempt from the notification requirement pursuant to OD 7.50 for the following reasons: (i) the Project will finance only rehabilitation 2 Data available from the former USSR Ministry of Health indicate that ammonia nitrates are 2 to 3 times higher, refinery waste products 8 times higher, copper and zinc 10 times higher, and phenol 20 times higher than former USSR norms.

Ground water originating from the Shollar and Hachmas Aquifers is of potable quality and treatment is not required. The combined production of these sources is about 4.0 m3/s, of which about 1.5 m3/s is used by the towns and villages along the way. The water flows by gravity to within 40 km of Baku before pumping is necessary. 2.5 The Jeiranbatan Treatment Works are located adjacent to the Jeiranbatan Reservoir. The yield from the reservoir for domestic water supply is about 10 m3/s. Constructed in various stages from 1961 to 1978, the treatment works are of traditional design and use a mixture of horizontal and upward flow settlement basins followed by rapid sand filters. Chlorination is provided at both inlet and outlet. Although still functioning, the treatment works are in need of urgent rehabilitation. 2.6 The Kura River Treatment Works, which are located about 140 km to the south of Baku at a point 45 km downstream from the confluence of the Kura and Araks Rivers, were constructed in two stages between 1971 and 1988. It is noteworthy that the treatment works are provided with presettlement tanks of unusual design based on radial flows and using polychromide as a coagulant. This unusual design, together with shortages of the coagulant, are creating conditions whereby suspended solids are not being sufficiently removed prior to conventional treatment. Under heavy sediment loads3 carried by the river, the conventional horizontal tanks and rapid gravity filters become overwhelmed, leading to inefficient chlorination and substandard water quality. In an attempt to overcome this problem, a start was made on constructing presettlement lagoons covering an area of almost 170 ha; however, due to lack of funds, these facilities have yet to be completed. 2.7 When operating at full capacity, the Jeiranbatan and Kura River Treatment Works can supply up to 20 m3/s of potable water. 2.8 Pumping Stations and Transmission Mains. All water from either the sources or treatment works must be pumped at some stage. There are 13 pumping station sites (see IBRD Map No. 26890), some with more than one pumping station and all with more than one combination of pumps. Most of the pumps and equipment are in very poor condition, so that equipment failure and service interruptions are common. Further, the stations comprise a number of incompatible combinations of pumps and motors, thus greatly reducing the overall efficiency of the system. In addition, most of the pumping stations lack operating and maintenance manuals; operators often are not familiar even with the basic instructions developed when the equipment was originally installed. Further, in most stations the pumps and motors are mounted on separate foundation blocks, making proper alignment of the pump and motor shafts almost impossible, thus resulting in excessive wear and frequent breakdowns. At prcsent, motor failure is reported to be the largest single cause of service interruptions. The electrical stepdown stations and transformers supplying power to the pumping stations are in equally poor condition. The poor condition of the booster pumps has meant that most residents living above the third floor must carry water from a standpipe on the ground floor to their apartments. The total water storage capacity for the Baku system is about 850,000 m3 or about 21 hours of estimated daily demand. In theory, capacity of this magnitude would normally be sufficient for diurnal and seasonal balancing of emergencies. However, some of the reservoirs are known to leak badly and the majority have not been cleaned for a number of years. Moreover, a considerable amount of sediment has accumulated in many of the reservoirs. This is suspected of being the major reason why recent water samples taken from the reservoirs show evidence of bacteriological and fecal contamination. In addition to the main service reservoirs, there are many smaller reservoirs owned and operated by district housing authorities. These reservoirs are outside the control of the BWA but are also known to leak and many have continuously running overflows. 2.12 Service Levels. About 95 percent of all households in Greater Baku are connected to the system. Water connections within Baku total about 42,000, of which 41,000 are domestic subscribers and just under 1,000 industrial. However, it is widely known that there also many illegal connections. About 10,000 meters have been installed over the years but fewer than 400 work. 2.13 Thus, while nearly all of Baku's households are considered officially connected to the public water supply system, on average water is available to individual families for only 22 days per month for a maximum of 11 hours per day. Reform Strategy 2.20 Rationale. The profile that emerges from the Baku water and sewerage sector comprises a number of different agencies and ministries, often with overlapping or unclear lines of authority. Each ministry has independently progressed into sectoral implementation tasks, thus impeding the efficient development of multisector planning, programming and budgeting initiatives. The result has been a piecemeal response to sectoral needs that has tended to focus on the installation of large-scale physical infrastructure facilities. Because many of these facilities were not operationally integrated into a program of asset maintenance and improvement at the planning and implementation stage, operating and maintenance requirements have traditionally assumed a low priority in the national budgeting process. Today, many of the infrastructure systems, especially the Greater Baku system, have regressed into a state of systemic degradation, exhibiting the accumulated effect of decades of inadequate maintenance. 2.21 Nevertheless, over the last three decades, the Government has made substantial investments in water infrastructure. However, the focus of this investment policy has been on the quantity of investments. Improving the quality of investments is also vital. Further, while the BWA is a public utility and should be perceived as a commercially oriented undertaking, it should be recognized that until recently it has always operated at a loss, never generating sufficient funds to meet day-to-day expenses nor to cover its working capital needs, or the contributions required to finance new works; the BWA became accustomed to operating as a highly subsidized institution, and its management philosophy has been deeply ingrained along these lines. This, coupled with the sectoral fragmentation at the national level and low operating efficiencies at the sectoral level, have all played a part in reducing the impact of the earlier investments and point to the need for a major reform initiative. Creating the institutional and organizational conditions that oblige the water agency to be more efficient and more responsive to the

This challenge will be addressed through a five-point intervention program: (i) creating a macro environment conducive to change; (ii) acquiring adequate working facilities; (iii) creating an appropriate institutional framework; (iv) establishing the internal capacity to manage reform; and (v) corporatizing the new agency. 2.22 Creating a Macro Environment Conducive to Reform. The Project will be the first Bank/IDA infrastructure investment operation in Azerbaijan. During the reconnaissance mission in January 1994, Bank/IDA was asked to consider making a sizeable credit to the Government to address the major problems associated with the water and sewerage sector in Greater Baku. It was concluded, however, that: (i) the cost of such a program would exceed all available resources for a single lending operation; and (ii) the current weak performance capacity of the designated institutions, including poor maintenance practices and low tariff levels, would preclude consideration of such an operation without substantial upfront institutional restructuring and financial reforms. It was agreed, therefore, that a longer-term development program divided into two or more phases would be the preferred strategic approach. 3.2 Current Phase. In this nexus of service requirements and financial constraints, an improved formal water supply service was clearly the first priority of Govermment in this sector. The 1994 reconnaissance mission concurred with this assessment. It was agreed with the Government that the first phase, which is covered by the proposed Project, will focus on addressing the widespread inefficiencies in the production and distribution of potable water through a major institutional reform initiative (paras 2.20-2.29). It was also agreed that, in terms of physical works, the first phase would be limited in scope and would comprise a five-year "time-slice" of the most urgent priority works that would have an immediate and demonstrable impact on improving the reliability and quality of water supply to domestic consumers and hence on the general living standards of the population. Such works would be characterized by relatively low costs and high benefits. Given the need to complete the sewerage master plan and the limited resources either at the Government level or with potential funding agencies, it was agreed to defer any sewerage investments to a second phase program. 3.3 Subsequent Phases. The Government recognizes that full rehabilitation of the Baku system will be a long and costly process. Second and subsequent Phases, therefore, will be aimed at water and sewerage network rehabilitation and possible expansion to existing capacity. It is noteworthy that the aggregate cost of dealing in a comprehensive way with the water and sewerage sector in Greater Baku is expected to be large. Rehabilitation of the water network alone will probably exceed US$300 million. Similarly, the collection and treatment of sewage is very expensive. Typical investment costs for collecting sewage from a household are approximately US$1,000. Treatment costs increase this amount to nearly US$1,500 for primary treatment alone. If these figures are applied to Greater Baku, this translates into a potential investment requirement of about US$600 million. For higher levels of

Peripheral communities and informal settlements that encroach on former industrial sites are particularly disadvantaged with regard to public water supply. Interventions in the Baku water supply, therefore, should be designed to meet the needs of specific communities. Community-tailored pilot projects will be important building blocks in the effort to improve the overall system. 11. An estimated 40 to 60 percent of public water is not paid for. Apart from illegal connections and leakages, one reason for lost water revenue is the overall lack of metering equipment. Only public institutions and industries have water meters. However, they neglect to pay water bills and fail to repair meters, as required by the local authorities. In turn, the local government is reluctant to enforce water payments because of the possible adverse impact on productivity and employment. 12. Most households in Baku have developed various strategies for coping with a poor quality, insufficient, and irregular public water supply. These strategies include boiling tap water (75 percent of all households), installing storage facilities (53 percent), drilling private wells (23 percent) and buying water from vendors (20 percent). Moreover, households incur high costs to secure additional, non-public water. On average, households spend about 17 times more on alternative water supplies than on their monthly water bills (1680 manat versus 100 manat) with the poor spending a significantly higher percent of their income (7 percent) on coping strategies than wealthier citizens (2 percent) (figure 1). Thus, low income households experience a much greater welfare loss from unreliable public water supply than households in higher income categories. Accordingly, the poor would profit the most from an improved supply system. 13. Although the inadequate water supply affects the entire population, low-income households suffer the most because they cannot resort to expensive coping strategies. To deal with an unreliable water supply, they are more likely to reduce the amount of water consumed rather than retrieve additional water from alternative sources. Among the poor, women and the elderly appear to bear the greatest burden of the water supply crisis. Women have the primary responsibility for fetching water from alternative supplies and for caring for family members who suffer from illnesses caused by unsafe water. The elderly, living on small retirement incomes, cannot afford to invest in alternative supply systems and have difficulties in fetching and carrying water from outside their homes. 14. Households would be willing to pay substantially more than their current monthly water charge for better public water service. In fact, 84 percent would consider it "fair" to pay twice the amount of their monthly bill (on average 100 manat) even without any improvements at all. A substantial portion of households (63 percent) is willing to pay over ten times the current level. The study revealed that poorer households are willing to spend a significantly higher share of their income (6 percent) on improved water services than better-off families (1 percent) (figure 1). Although these figures seem to be extremely high, especially the ones for the poor, they become more realistic when seen in relation to current coping expenditures. The average household now spends 1680 manat per month to cope with inadequately piped water supply, thus a willingness to pay up to 2000 manat for a reliable public water service actually corresponds to a household's real experience.

The extent of the Baku water supply crisis is clearly evident when water quantities lost through leaks are compared to quantities actually consumed by households. While the average Baku family uses around 300 liters of public water per day, it loses at the same time 1.3 times more (a daily total of 400 liters). On a per capita basis, these figures are 80 liters and 100 liters respectively. Real per capita water consumption (not including losses) for various household activities lies at about 80 liters per day, well below western average of 200 to 300 liters per day. Per capita water consumption is highest on low floor levels (1-3rd floor: 82.5 liters per day), considerably lower on middle floor levels (4-6th floor: 75.6 liters), and lowest on high levels (above 6th floor). This correlates with better water pressure and supply on low floor levels. In order to consume even these small amounts, high-floor residents have to store more water than their neighbors below. While up to the sixth floor around 15 liters are stored daily per capita, this amount increases significantly to 20 liters per day on higher floor levels (figure 2). 16. With respect to the relationship between household size and water consumption, the survey revealed that larger households use more water than smaller families. However, the situation is reversed when per capita consumption is used as a criterion. In this case, large households (over 6 persons) have a much lower real per capita water consumption (47 liters/day) than medium-sized households (4 to 6 persons; 64 liters/day) and small families (1 to 3 persons, 106 liters/day), with high statistical significance (figure 3). Given the current water tariff system, introduced by Kommunpromvod in December 1994 and based on household size (US$.07 per household member/month), the bigger a family, the higher the tariff per liter of public water consumed. This clearly suggests that the water agency should base its tariffs on water quantity consumed by individual recipients. Of course such a system would require water metering, which to date exists only for public institutions and industries. 17. The findings derived from the rapid household and industrial surveys and agreed by key stakeholders had clear implications for the design and implementation of the Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project. The following highlights implications for the current project and future investments. Project-Specific Implications 26. The proposed project meets one of the most critical needs of the city's 2.5 million population and will be particularly beneficial to the poor. Major improvements in the water supply system will be achieved at an investment cost of less than US$18 per person. The rapid participatory assessment of over 400 households and discussions with members of two major NGOs representing vulnerable groups of women and displaced populations both strongly indicate full beneficiary support for the project. 27. Savings will include the conservation of the water resource itself, the time and energy spent fetching, transporting, storing, boiling and filtering water, the gas and electricity used for water boiling and for pumping from individual wells and pipes to overhead storage units, and the reduced costs of ill health as measured by foregone labor productivity and medical expenses. 28. The success of this project in improving the reliability of water delivery will enhance trust in the service itself, and will provide public support for other components of the Goverrnent's reform agenda. By meeting the basic need for water through institutional development measures that focus on institutional autonomy, commercialization of the utility sector and participation of stakeholders, the project can help to set the stage for similar reforms in the delivery of other infrastructure services. 29. Improvements in the reliability of the water supply will create clear opportunities for cost recovery. The strongly perceived need for the project and the high cost of coping strategies adopted to mitigate adverse impacts of unreliability reveal preferences for a reliable water supply at a level of affordability that could justify tariff increases to at least five times the current levels for the household sector. These increases, however, would have to be complemented by an adequate metering system and the elimination of illegal connections. 30. Sufficient cost recovery by Kommunpromvod will be a crucial prerequisite for a better repair and maintenance performance. A system of water charges is needed that endows the water agency with operational and financial autonomy for the efficient and sustainable delivery of services. The current

Although actual water use may be comparatively low presently (80 to 120 liters/day), they are likely to increase substantially once the technical and institutional improvements are initiated. Currently, public water is treated as a scarce good and generally used efficiently because it is not always available. Sustainable conservation efforts among the population will only be reached through a pricing strategy that is economically viable and socially equitable. Of course the effectiveness of this measure will depend on the installation of properly functioning and well maintained water meters to allow a quantity based tariff structure. 31. The implementation of the community metering programs will take into account the specific conditions of each community covered by the project. To help ensure the effectiveness of household metering, the program should be implemented first where households already have low leakage and 24 hours of continuous supply as well as garden plots. Moreover, it will be necessary to ensure strong comnuunity mobilization and public education and outreach programs to support the community household leakage repair program. All of these measures will help to promote water resource conservation and are included in the project. 32. Given the need for overall improvement in cost recovery by the water agency from all industry groups, an adequately designed debt repayment schedule for enterprises will be necessary. At the same time, ongoing consumption must be correctly metered and paid for not only for effective cost recovery, but to ensure the sustainability of water resources. Implications for Future Investment 33. Although in the late 1980s adequate public water supply was a major concern of Baku's industries, water related issues have lost their priority ranking to the economic hardship experienced by enterprises in the last few years. Once the regional conflicts in neighboring areas are solved, and the influx of western investment and technology in connection with the exploration of oil fields in the Caspian Sea reaches expected dimensions, industries will recover rapidly, and public water, potable and technical, will once again be in high demand. This assumption is strengthened by the fact that, out of all branches, the oil industry, which can be expected to grow faster than any other industrial branch in the near future, consumes by far the largest share of potable water (40 percent). According to the most optimistic forecasts for industrial development in Baku in the next ten years, potable water consumption by enterprises may be as high as 160 m3/year in 2005, 10 percent higher than water consumption during the last peak period of production in 1989. In addition to industrial water demand, potable water use by households and comnunal institutions is expected to increase to 600 m3 in the same time period, an amount 25 percent higher than the quantity of potable water consumed by the population in the peak year of 1993. Institutional Organization of Water Supply 4. Responsibility for the production and distribution of water in Azerbaijan is divided among a number of Central Government departments. The Ministry of Irrigation (MOI) is responsible for the development and allocation of surface water resources, while the Department of Geology controls and license groundwater extraction. The MOI has the responsibility for water supply to rural areas, both for private consumption and irrigation. 5. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is responsible for setting the quality standards for drinking water while the State Ecology Committee (SEC) is responsible for regulating environmental standards. The production and distribution facilities of Kommunpromvod are in a state of severe degradation caused by the virtual absence, over the past two decades, of expenditure for asset maintenance and replacement. Also, due to the lack of systematic planning of network extensions, exacerbated by the lack of adequate financial resources, the distribution system is poorly configured. 10. Based on western standards, the total design capacity of water production exceeds needs by a factor of about two. In spite of this, the supply of water to consumers is unreliable and services are provided for only part of the day. Estimated water losses from leakage, illegal connections, and wastage amount to as much as 70 percent of production. Because of low pressures in the distribution system, consumers living in elevated parts of the city or on top floors of apartment buildings frequently have no services at all. Also, it is suspected sewage inflow through leaks in the distribution network causes contamination of drinking water. Mortality from waterborne diseases, especially among children, is high, and in 1993 Baku experienced an outbreak of cholera which was ascribed to the poor condition of the water system. Due to an inadequate billing system, undercharging consumption by a large margin, politically determined tariffs, and inefficient revenue collection, operating income currently just covers cash expenses, without allowance for maintenance. Although recently tariff increases for water charges leave tended to keep pace with inflation, taken over a longer period tariffs have decreased sharply in real terms. The Greater Baku Water Authority (Kommunpromvod--BWA) was established by charter in 1989 to provide water supply to the Baku Metropolitan Area and the Aspheron Peninsula. The headquarters and key managers of the Baku Water Company and its subsidiary, the Baku Water Distribution Company, are located in a small building in the central part of the city. Management is characterized by a top-down style inherited from the previous Soviet system, with all decisions centrally controlled and micromanagement pervasive. On the other hand, many of the key administrative and financial functions of these companies are handled by offices scattered across metropolitan Baku, which is the consequence of inadequate space at the headquarters facility. Generally there is extremely limited collection and reporting of information vital to the commercial management of the water company and ineffective enforcement of collection of arrears. The authorities are instead forced to spend much of their time responding to the latest crisis in the water supply and distribution system. 3. The nine subdepots of BWD show a full staff complement, including a manager, two senior supervisory engineers, a personnel officer, payroll clerk, cashier, technical teams of three to four people, and field personnel at pumping stations and workshops (often nearly one-third of total staff). The lines of reporting are idiosyncratic (basically technically rather than managerially oriented), and hiring often mirrors social realities of the past and present (pensioners comprise most of the laborers at the pumping stations and in the workshops, and some returning veterans of the Nagorno-Karabagh conflict have been hired). 4. Operationally, large water main bursts remain unrepaired close to district headquarters (some of which are controlled by makeshift dikes), which underscores the inadequacy of the water company to address even the most obvious leaks a few yards from its own facilities. There are also numerous and clearly visible illegal water connections into urban communities, including near reservoirs in Greater Baku. This points to a severe lack of institutional capacity and responsiveness at the most basic operational level. Clearly, commercial operations are impossible under these chaotic circumstances. Moreover, rusted generators and miscellaneous, mostly unusable spare parts litter workshop grounds, and most buildings are dilapidated, underdimensioned, and should to be razed. Many personnel appear to be idle, awaiting the next emergency repair they will be unable to effectively make because they lack the means to do so. 5. The reason for this deplorable state of affairs is readily apparent: inadequate, inappropriate/inoperable, or (usually) nonexistent equipment; an inability to coordinate even the little existing capacity effectively; and a dramatic need for comprehensive technical and managerial training throughout BWA, which will be required to restore order to the water sector of Greater Baku. All of the foregoing renders the institutional incapacity of BWA an issue of considerable social significance as well.  ANNEX H Paige 1 of 12 BAKU WATER SUPPLY REHABILITATION PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS Environmental Overview and Evaluation A. Project Impact and Environmental Rating 1. The Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project, as an emergency project, is designed to address urgent operational and administrative needs of the water sector. The project has been assigned a category B rating. No significant environmental effects are anticipated other than a slight increase in vehicular traffic in some parts of the city and some disruption in traffic flows caused by pipelines being replaced. Mitigating measures will be taken to abate noise and dust from construction activities as well as to redirect traffic so as not to impede normal flows unnecessarily or for extended periods. There will also be a slight increase in sewage flows as a result of increased water pressure; however, the increase in water supply in targeted areas and better water quality will offset this effect. A sewage operation is planned as a second phase following implementation of the proposed rehabilitation project. The expected operational and administrative improvements under the current project should quicken the pace of implementing a subsequent operation to improve the sewage situation of the Apsheron Peninsula. B. Synopsis of Environmental Issues 2. The Apsheron Peninsula, which includes the capital city of Baku, is one of the three most industrialized regions in the FSU. Its ecosystem is now replete with the residue and legacy of nearly a century of environmental neglect. Importantly, this area is one of the oldest oil-producing regions in the world. As a consequence of oil exploitation, as well as intense industrialization under the Soviets, the surface and underground hydrosphere has caused 7,000 ha. of land to be polluted the Bay of Baku (with environmental impact on those who live near the Bay or walk along its perimeter), and engendered serious pollution of the Caspian Sea. 3. In the water sector, wastes leaking from poor sewage network into the ground, industrial contamination, generally inadequate water treatment, and unreliable water supply and distribution pose serious social, health, even industrial problems. Most of the groundwater resources are contaminated by industrial and municipal wastes dumped or discharged haphazardly. Only a small number of industrial plants pretreat their effluent before discharge to the sewers. The majority discharge raw effluent that jeopardizes the municipal sewage network and the biological treatment process at Govsani sewage works. The source of pollution in the city water distribution network is the inflow of dirty ground water or cross- contamination with the sewage.' The Baku Water Company for many years has lacked the means to address any of the myriad of problems besetting the water sector in the Apsheron Peninsula. 4. Large quantities of municipal and industrial wastes are discharged directly into the sea, affecting the marine ecology and making the Bay of the Baku a biological dead zone, with several consequences to the local health profile and the economy. Additionally, the rising level of the Caspian 'Lack of sewage network, made that in part of the city the surface water sewer have been converted into sewage.
 ANNEX H Page 2 of 12 BAKU WATER SUPPLY REHABILITATION PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS sea is causing problems with ground water quality in many areas along the peninsula. 5. The incidence of medically determined waterborne diseases in Baku remained relatively stable over the last decade, ranging between 634 and 797 per 100,000 inhabitants, but with a significant increase in 1993 to 985 per 100,000. This surge will need to be monitored given the recent outbreak of cholera in the country. In two regions within greater Baku, Azbekov and Sabunhinsky, there is direct relationship between water quality and epidemic diseases, where as much as 30 percent of the population suffers from unacceptable water quality. 6. In addition, many housing areas and settlements on the Peninsula lack proper sewage collection and disposal facilities. In the absence of municipal sewage collection capacity, residents, both individuals and groups, have installed private systems, which discharge wastes directly into the nearest lake or ground soakway. Nearly 60 percent of Baku now lacks an appropriate sewage system. 7. A further problem pertains to health care institutions themselves, which directly discharge unsterilized wastes into the municipal sewage network. None of the 92 hospitals and 11 medical institutes in the Baku area are equipped with adequate facilities for treatment of their wastes before discharging into the water and sewage network. 8. Finally, there is a notable absence of realistic environmental standards and enforcement mechanisms. Although the Soviets developed rigorous standards, evidence suggest thy were seldom applied. Over time several industries developed their own environmental bureaus that theoretically monitored environmental impact; however, clearly self-policing has never worked. The result is widespread lack of coordination of environmental policies and standards. 9. Institutionally, ineffective structure stemmed from the past sectoral division of the countrv by the ministries together with their institutional capacities, lack of coordination, political influence, and lack of clear lines of responsibility. There are four agencies involved currently in environmental monitoring and about 200 monitoring sites, including monitoring of the marine ecosystem, freshwater, groundwater and atmospheric pollution. In the current austere economic climate, lack of resources has seriously constrained all such activities, including research. 10. Recently, the State Ecological Committee drafted a package of environrmental legislation that incorporates international experience and concerns in the country. This legislation was submitted for parliamentary action in the spring of 1994 and is still pending. Additionally, the National Sanitary Board, in cooperation with the State Ecology Committee, has prepared a manual that would establish national environmental standards, which also awaits parliamentary approval. 11. The following discussion describes in detail the environmental problems facing Azerbaijan in the project area, some of which will be addressed under the proposed loan.
 ANNEX H Page 3 of 12 BAKU WATER SUPPLY REHABILITATION PROJECT ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS C. Overview of the Water Sector Water Supply Sources and Quality 12. Baku City and the Apsheron Peninsula are fed with water from three principal sources: Shollar and Hachmas intakes, Jeiranbatan reservoir, and the Kura river. In addition, there is local exploitation of ground water. For the public potable system, the water from the Shollar and Hachmas intakes requires only chlorination. The water from Jeiranbatan reservoir and Kura river receives full treatment at two large treatment works. There is no systematic collection of water quality data on exploitation from ground sources. Available data from research studies confirmed a wide range water quality depending on the source. 13. Sources of drinking water supply include Shollar and Hachmas intakes, with a flow rate of 1.27 m3/s. They are named after towns located 180 km north of Baku. Both intakes are fed by underground water of sediments of quaternary age represented lithologically by gravel and mixed sands. The water bearing strata are protected against vertically migrating pollutants by relatively thick clay rocks. The water from these intakes is fresh and meets national standards for potable water. Mineralization ranges between 1-3 and 15-30 g/l and more. The water composition is chloride- sulphate and chloride-hydrocarbonate sodium. 14. The Jeiranbatan reservoir, situated 25 km north of Baku, is supplied by the Samuron canal, built in 1956, with a total storage volume of 186.6 Mm3 and a useful storage capacity of 150.3 Mm3. The Samuron canal carries freshwater originating in a mountainous area that is thinly populated, with no large industries. After treatment, water quality meets national standards (GOST 2874-82). Solid residuals range between 126426 mg/I, and total hardness from 2 to 14 mgeq/l. Among anions, hydrocarbonates (177-647 mg/l) dominate over sulphates (32-236 mg/1) and chlorides (4-16 mg/1). Last summer light algae blooms were observed in some areas of the reservoir, which confirmed potential for airborne or agricultural pollution. The unfavorable location of the reservoir and lack of buffer zone will need to be addressed to minimize this source of water pollution. 15. Lack of reliable environmental monitoring data make estimation the scale and nature of Kura river pollution extremely difficult to measure. There are many examples where estimations are too general or contradictory. Lack of industrial and municipal treatment facilities in the river basin as well as intensive agriculture production (cotton) in the river's upper reaches lead to the conclusion that riverain water is polluted. The hydrochemical composition and quality of riverain water are related to the intensity of industrial production, community infrastructure, and the type of agricultural activity in the basin. Water that belongs to the sulphate-hydrocarbonate category of sodium or calcium group, with very high natural turbidity, varies seasonally, ranging from 500 to 60,000 mg/I. 16. Groundwater in the peninsula appears sporadically. In the western part, it appears in the form of patches and in the east and around Baku it occurs everywhere at a depth of 1-30m. The quality of water depends on the area, i.e, salinization typically varies between 1 to 50 g/l and more. The best quality of water resources can be found near or in Bilga, Buzavna, and Mandakyan. Water is poorly mineralised (1-3 mg/1) and reaches almost 90,000 m3/d.

As a consequence of the rise in the level of the Caspian Sea, in several areas in the east part of the peninsula (e.g., Guzavny), water from the dikes has begun flooding settlements and arable cultivated fields. 18. Most of the groundwater resources are contaminated by industrial and municipal wastes dumped or discharged in the area. The source of water pollution in the distribution system is inflow of dirty ground water, accumulated due to bursts of sewerage and water supply pipes. Open-cast mines and rubbish dumps filled with water are possible sources of pollution, not only for the distribution pipework but for reservoirs as well. 2 Underground water that is unprotected from pollutants in the natural environment should only be used by industries, which today is not the case. 19. About 1,300,000 m3/day has been estimated by the Baku Sewage Company as the total quantity of sewage generated within the Baku administrative area. Other calculations indicate that the quantity may be about half this amount, and that the per capita volumes of sewage generated are about half of the values of official estimates. 21. Nearly 60% of Baku is not provided with communal sewerage. Hence, waste water from Azizbekov, Bingadi, Surachani, and the Nizami-Karadag region is discharged into lakes and pits in the neighborhood. Only a few of them are connected to the sewage network, while the others use septic tanks, allowing wastes to penetrate the groundwater. Environment and Health Issues 36. The main findings of the environmental analysis showed that low quality of drinking water and related health risk are mainly caused by the poor condition of both water supply and sewage systems in the city, which creates the potential for cross-contamination of the drinking water by leaking sewage and industrial wastes. 37. Lack of adequately designed special waste disposal sites, which would meet sanitary requirements for toxic waste; damage to sewage pipes; the absence of sewerage in some districts of Baku; poorly operated reservoirs and water distribution networks; and excessive air pollution--all have aggravated the ecological situation of the Apsheron Peninsula and the City of Baku, and negatively affected the health of the population. The total incidence of the medically determined waterborne and water diseases in Baku has remained relatively stable over the last 10 years at between 634 to 797 per 100,000 population, but with a significant rise to 985 in 1993. 38. Whereas in the Baku diseases can be related to several causes, in the city of Sumgait there is a clear link between diseases there and industrial activities. Some of the chemicals produced there are carcinogens, especially chlororganic products such as hexachlorane, DDT, Lindane, etc. Others cause severe birth defects and embriotoxic effects. On average, 27 out of 1,000 newborns do not survive the first year and others are affected by numerous illnesses. On the other hand, the majority of industrial plants in Baku or the Apsheron Peninsula have been developed without environmental control equipment or adequate buffer zones. 39. The only regions in Greater Baku where there is an evident relationship between the quality of water and epidemic diseases are the Azbekov and Sabunhinsky regions, where it is reported that about 30% of the population suffers from unacceptable water quality.

Degradation of the environment in the Baku Metropolitan area can be largely attributed to the inherent inefficiencies of a centrally planned economy. Centralized, ineffective enforcement of environmental laws and standards, an inefficient system of environmental management, and lack of public participation in the process of environmental protection and management, has resulted in the degradation of the environment. 41. Most of the environmental issues described above result from lack of an environmental legal and regulatory framework, including a permit system and appropriate industrial zoning. Improvement of city planning based on realistic environmental standards and regulations is a matter of urgency. 42. Environmental protection is currently under the supervision of the following institutions: State Committee for Ecology and its 25 regional offices, which is placed under the authority of the Office of the President; the State Committee for Hydrometerology; the Ministry of Agriculture; and the Ministry of Construction. In addition, within the Ministry of Health, the Sanitary-Epidemiological Authority is responsible for monitoring water quality relative to public health. 43. There is a urgent need to upgrade the existing environmental monitoring system in two respects: first, the Baku Water Company will need to monitor water quality in the reservoirs and distribution system in the city; and second Hydromet will need to monitor the quality of the Kura river Samuron channel. Lack of resources caused a recent reduction in existing potential to monitor water quality. 44. A significant amount of expertise and training will be required at all levels to strengthen the enforcement capabilities for dealing with polluters who do not comply with the conditions established by environmental permits and licenses. 45. The environmental monitoring structure system in the Republic has been developed according to the past sectoral administrative division of the country, which involves a number of ministries.
