In view of the evolving situation of the banking sector in Central Asia, a number of minimum conditions should be met by banks to be selected to hold IBRD Special Account funds, as specified below: a. financial soundness and stabilitv: the banks should have received a general operating license from the Central Bank of Azerbaijan. Moreover, any bank selected for a Special Account should be subject to an assessment by an IBRD Task Manager in consultation with the Disbursement Officer to ensure that it meets adequate standards for financial soundness. b. audit: the bank should have been audited by a recognized auditing firm for the past year and the audit report must be found acceptable to the Bank. c. reasonable fees: even the most competitive banks charge high fees for each transaction, although they claim to be making profits on the cash value of their operations rather than on the number of transactions. However, they are ready to negotiate their fees down and in some instances some of the banks were willing to waive their charges for the benefit of holding IBRD Special Account funds. d. foreign correspondent bank network: the bank should have a significant network of correspondent banks for all major currencies (USD, DM, FF, SWF, Pounds Sterling) and the capacity to handle transactions with foreign banks on a routine basis. References on an Azeri bank can be obtained from its correspondent banks abroad. e. full bankinz services: the bank should be capable of performing a wide range of banking services (wire transfers to foreign banks, cash withdrawals, issuance of monthly Special Account statements/debit notes, issuance of conversion rate). as the Azeri banking system does not provide checks, small payments covering operating cost will be covered by cash withdrawals. In some instances, the banks may not be favorable to small cash withdrawals; ii. Azeri banks typically do not provide regular monthly statements to their customers. They provide debit notes only for the larger transactions. Implementing agencies have been able to obtain monthly statements as required by IBRD at an extra charge. In one instance, the statement was prepared by the implementing agency and certified by the bank, which is not recommended under IBRD rules. f. capacity to issue letter of credit: most banks have limited experience in issuing Letters of Credit and even less so in obtaining Letter of Credit confirmations from foreign banks. The size of the Letter of Credit department and the volume of operations handled should

Such a letter is a precondition for the Bank to disburse the initial authorized allocation. i. training/familiarity with Western banking practices: the staff from the foreign transactions department should possess a good knowledge of the English language and should normally have been trained by the former "Vnesheconombank" or by foreign commercial banks abroad or in Azerbaijan. j. annual rePorts/statement of fees: a bank should be willing to provide information of this nature, satisfactory of IBRD. Selection Procedures 2. It is recommended that the selection of a bank to hold a Special Account should be based on competitive local shopping procedure. To initiate this process an implementing agency would send to at least three commercial banks a letter inviting them to submit proposals. This should be done on project by project basis and the bank's proposals would be tailored to the size of the Special Account under each loan and possibly the borrowing sector. This procedure would best protect the interest of borrowers in the long run as well as foster transparency and facilitate disbursement of loan funds. This process will also provide the implementing agency with a written commitment from the bank, which should result in better control of funds. 3. Low income household - income for the low income household is set at 45% of the average, which corresponds to approximately US$ 20 per month. Average family size for both average-income and low-income households is 4.5 persons (source: Baku Social Assessment Survey, July 1994).

doc.repnme: Azerbaijan - Greater Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The primary objectives of the Greater Baku Water Supply Rehabilitation Project are to: 1) make emergency short term improvements in the water supply system to restore the water supply to Baku, in particular to the poorer elements of the population; 2) improve the water supply system as a whole; and 3) provide the basis for longer term planning and recovery. The project will comprise five major components: 1) water demand management to conserve water at the household level through a program of consumer awareness initiatives, through repairs to in-home plumbing, valves, taps and other fittings, and by rationalizing water use through meter installations and the implementation of a progressive water tariff; 2) operations and maintenance improvements to increase the amount of water available from the distribution system through a program of leak detection and repair, workshop and equipment acquisition, and at least a one year inventory of selected replacement valves and pipes; 3) supply improvements to improve the quantity and quality of water from the treatment works and enhancing the reliability of the distribution network ; 4) institutional capacity building to reorganize the water utility into a joint stock company; consolidating its offices; purchasing and installing new computers with new software; and developing training programs; and 5) preparation and implementation of a national policy framework for the water sector and preparing a regional master plan.
